title: England’s former top doctor: Ban eating on public transport
text:
Former Chief Medical Officer of England Sally Davies | Chris J Ratcliffe/Getty Images | Oli Scarff/Getty Images England’s former top doctor: Ban eating on public transport Ex-chief medical officer calls for the national sugar tax to cover milk-based drinks.

England’s former chief medical officer, Sally Davies, on Thursday called for a ban on eating and drinking on urban public transport and an extension of the country’s sugar tax, in her final report addressing childhood obesity.

Obesity affects on average one-fifth of primary-school kids, said Davies, adding that exercise alone will not solve the problem. In the report, which is independent from government, Davies sets out a plethora of recommendations to tackle the issue.

Most eye-catching is the ban on eating or drinking on public transport, which is explained as a way for children to grow up “free from marketing, signals and incentives to consume unhealthy food and drinks.” (Breastfeeding, drinking water and eating or drinking for a medical condition would be exempt.)

Davies also floats the possibility of introducing standardized packaging for food, which is already used for tobacco, as well as phasing out of all advertising for unhealthy foods and drinks.

In addition, she called for the national sugar tax to cover milk-based drinks — something that Prime Minister Boris Johnson has said would hit the poorest the hardest. However, Davies offered up evidence that children in the most deprived areas in fact benefit the most from the sugar levy.

The government isn't under any obligation to follow through with her recommendations, but Health Secretary Matt Hancock said that his department would study the report closely “and act on the evidence.”
description: Ex-chief medical officer calls for the national sugar tax to cover milk-based drinks.
